The image shows a portion of what appears to be an official document, likely a Belgian déclaration de succession (declaration of inheritance) form. The visible text reads:

Reçu le 4 mars novembre 1949 déclaré

This line is handwritten at the top of the document and appears to be a date stamp or receipt notation. It translates to:

"Received on 4 March November 1949 declared"

There seems to be an error or confusion in the date, as it lists both March and November. This could be a mistake in writing or possibly indicating a range or correction.

Below this handwritten line, there is some pre-printed text on the form, which is partially visible:

(1) Les déclarations rectificatives et supplémentaires portent le numéro de la déclaration qu'ils rectifient, affecté d'un exposant. (Circ. n° 1374, § 5, note 11).

This appears to be an instruction or note regarding how to number rectifying or supplementary declarations.

At the far right of the image, there's another printed notation:

(3) Négliger les centimes.

This instructs to disregard cents or centimes when filling out the form.

4_13: The image shows a portion of an old document, likely a Belgian administrative form. The visible text reads: Soixante & dix huit novembre 1919 (enreg[istré]) This translates to: "Seventy-eight November 1919 (registered)" It's worth noting that "Soixante & dix huit" is an older or more formal way of writing "soixante-dix-huit" (seventy-eight). This appears to be a date entry on the document, indicating it was registered or processed on November 78, 1919. The use of "78" for the day is unusual and might be an error, as November only has 30 days. At the top of the image, there's also a partial line of printed text that seems to be instructions or a header for the form, but it's cut off and not fully legible in this image.

The image shows a portion of what appears to be an official document, likely a Belgian déclaration de succession. The visible text reads:

Jeudi 8 deux décembre 1919 Verviers

This translates to:

"Thursday, December 8, 1919 Verviers"

Verviers is a city in Belgium, which fits with the document's origin. The date format is written out in words for the day and month, which was common in formal documents of that era.

There's also a footnote marker (1) visible at the bottom of the image, but the actual footnote text is cut off.

The rest of the document appears to be a pre-printed form with lines and boxes, typical of official documents from the early 20th century.

N° [Number]  
DATE DU DÉPÔT des DÉCLARATIONS [Date of filing of declarations]  
DÉSIGNATION DES PERSONNES DÉCÉDÉES OU ABSENTES [Designation of deceased or absent persons]  
- NOMS [Surnames]  
- PRÉNOMS [First names]  
- DOMICILES [Addresses]  
DATE DU DÉCÈS ou de la présomption d'absence [Date of death or presumption of absence]  
NOMS, PRÉNOMS ET DEMEURES DES PARTIES DÉCLARANTES [Names, first names and residences of the declaring parties]  
DROITS DE SUCCESSION [Inheritance rights]  
en LIGNE COLLATÉRALE et de MUTATION EN LIGNE DIRECTE [in collateral line and direct line mutation]  
- ACTIF [Assets]  
- PASSIF [Liabilities]  
- RESTANT NET [Net remainder]  
DROIT DE MUTATION par décès [Death transfer tax]  
NUMÉROS des DÉCLARATIONS [Declaration numbers]  
RECETTE [Revenue]  
- DATE  
- NUMÉROS du registre [Register numbers]  
DROITS ET AMENDES [Rights and fines]  
DATE  
N°  
OBSERVATIONS [Observations]
